answer: It might be your hard skills that get you the interview, but it’s the soft skills that bring you success in your career. Soft skills are your personal capabilities that determine how well you work with others, job performance, communication and all of the other things that make you different from every other expert in your field. While your technical expertise is very important, soft skills are much harder to teach. These can be a deciding factor in getting and keeping your dream job. In this post, we’ll outline nine soft skills that will make you successful in your career or in the classroom, and some tips to help you develop them further. Interpersonal communication is the backbone of all soft skills. It trains your brain to focus on positive things and makes you think of what you already have in your life as opposed to what you do not.It keeps you grounded in your personal life so you are less focused on what others are doing with theirs, which is a huge waste of time and won’t help you get any closer to your personal goals.How to practice it? Each morning, take 5 minutes to write down or say aloud 3 things you are grateful for having in your life right now. answer: You will appreciate the value and the relative significance of Soft Skills better if you understand the relationship between Hard Skills and Soft Skills more clearly. This analogy will help you for better understanding. Hard Skills are like the Hardware of a computer whereas the Soft Skills can be compared to a Software. As you know, the Hardware is an essential part of the computer without which the computer cannot work at all. However, imagine what would be the real value and usefulness of even a costly computer if it is not combined with the suitable and necessary software. Will it be able to deliver the results ? answer: What is soft skills? A set of skills that helps you do well in inter-personal communication. The main components of communication would be speaking, writing, reading and listening. Soft skills include qualities like being able to customise your communication and body language, assertive skills, negotiations, stress management, time management etc. If you ask me, working on your communication skills alone can make your soft skills better. A few ways to do that would be: 1. Reading: Read something every single day. And I don’t mean just newspapers. Read books – from fiction to non-fiction. (Image courtesy_google) According to the National Council on Measurement in Education, a certification test is a credentialing test used to determine whether individuals are knowledgeable enough in a given occupational area to be labeled "competent to practice" in that area. In simple words, when someone else decides that you are competent enough or not! It’s very important in very technical domains like Medical, IT and Engineering because there is only one right way. answer: Madison Wang It's great you are thinking of advancing your soft skills while you are still in college. Team assignments and club activities are the best and most accessible ways you can learn and practice your soft skills while in college. Team assignments: you know how a lot of students dread team assignments? Based on what I remembered from my own college days, plus stories I heard from our college interns, the most challenging part is to get your teammates to do their part of the work, and occasionally resolve conflicts among teammates. So next time you have to work in a team, volunteer to be the team lead, and see what you can do to make sure your fellow teammates do their work on time, without resenting you or each other. A few suggestions come to mind: Make sure everyone is clear what they need to woContinue Reading Continue Reading

answer: There is a lot of scope depending on the area of training you choose. Soft Skills a vast area and it is not a good idea to try and train everyone on everything. So one of the first things you should do is to figure out the niche you want to be an expert in. Build your personal brand accordingly. SKILLS REQUIRED AS A CORPORATE TRAINER Confidence: I don’t just mean confidence that you can train but also facing people and talking to them. You should preferably be an extrovert and like meeting people and working with people. Confidence is also being able to talk well and be able to hold people’s attention while you do that. If facing people gives you the jitters, this isn’t the right career for you. Communication skills: This term itself is pregnant with meaning. answer: Soft skills is a pretty large area, covering from Communication Skills, Listening Skills, Leadership Skills, Motivating Skills, Negotiation Skills… just to name a few. If you try to do too many things at the same time, you won’t succeed at anything. So it may be better to focus on 1 or 2 of these skills which you think you are weak at, or would like to improve further. One of the biggest skill that you must master is to be good at Communications… with your peers, your subordinates, your bosses, vendors, friends, pretty much every one. Communication goes much deeper than simply speaking… although speaking alone is not easy. To communicate effectively and efficiently, you must be able to talk and listen attentively. Then put across your points concisely. answer: Report writing is by far the top soft skill for an engineer. An engineer who is also a good writer can work on multiple tasks and across disciplines and has far better chances to progress in their career than a less soft skilled engineer. He or she can move from technical tasks to project management and business development roles. I give you a personal example. When I started as structural engineer, I struggled to put together a few sentences and write the reports I was asked to produce by my manager. He was an excellent writer and good communicator who from a technical role moved up the ladder to be a company director. I badly wanted to be like him but it wasn't until I migrated to Australia and became a manager that my writing skills took off. answer: It might be your hard skills that get you the interview, but it’s the soft skills that bring you success in your career. Soft skills are your personal capabilities that determine how well you work with others, job performance, communication and all of the other things that make you different from every other expert in your field. While your technical expertise is very important, soft skills are much harder to teach. These can be a deciding factor in getting and keeping your dream job. In this post, we’ll outline nine soft skills that will make you successful in your career or in the classroom, and some tips to help you develop them further. Interpersonal communication is the backbone of all soft skills.
